course_title: Topics in Afr American Studies: Mass Incarceration, Policing

class_notes: This course offers an introduction to and a general overview of the history of imprisonment in relation to the struggles for Black political freedom in the United States. It tracks a genealogy of the prison and practices of policing from the regimes of racial slavery. While the course is attentive to the sociological literature on mass incarceration past and present, the objective of the course is to think conceptually about the abstraction of racial slavery and anti-blackness as they continue to undercut systemic and institutionalized forms of inequality, punitive practices, and carcerality in the United States. For example, how might we draw the connections between the present-day protests against police brutality and extra-judicial practices of anti-black murder with a broader history of slavery and lynching in the US? How might we also consider the racial health inequities presented by the pandemic as both a signal of the lack of medical care and clinical services for African Americans and as a longer historical pandemic of medical violence that stems from the collusion between slavery, the prison, and the clinic? The course, thus, presents a broader view of imprisonment and policing beyond the brick and mortar site of the prison with a particular focus on Black feminist activism and radical practices of resistance to imprisonment and policing.
course_description: This course explores one of a wide range of topics pertaining to the African American experience in the fields of human and civil rights, social and literary texts, and the social sciences.
